comments.commentBody: stop the nonsense! The Tsarnaevs got political asylum from Chechnya.

It is shameful that while Sweden and Germany are willing to take a million of
refugees, the US, that mighty country , does´t take any responsibility
for its adventures overseas, and take charge of its own doing. Or , as you
prefer, Pay the Bill !.
It is .. frankly, .amazing.

Obama did not fail. It is the Congress that has failed to rise above unwarranted fear mongering and passed such a reprehensible piece of legislation. It is the same type of fear that pushed us into the invasion of Iraq (we are fighting there, so we will not have to fight here.) I also fear it will lead people who should know better, but are too afraid of "public opinion" to do what is sensible. I am afraid we may be headed back to deep military involvement in the Middle East, where we have virtually no true vital interests.
We are a nation of immigrants. I also wonder how many of the ancestors of
current Members of Congress would have made it in with this type of restrictive legislation. Let us hope there are enough sensible members of the Senate who will sustain Obama's veto.

Please enlighten us on what Obama won a Nobel Peace Prize for (tip; he won it even before he took office as US Prez)?

Obama has proven to be a terrible negotiator with Congress. Those are skills he lacks and he is lazy.

"You can't fight emotion with facts." Well when the emotions are pointing in an ignorant direction, shouldn't somebody at least try to do the right thing? Rouse themselves to make that effort?

He won a Nobel Peace Prize. The idea that the President should cower in the face of fear mongering -- no. History will do right by him on this.
You are spot on!!!

So, we should have denied entry to the late 19th and early 20th centuries Italian immigrants he off chance that their children and grandchildren might become members of the Mafia?  Same for German immigrants?  And for others, too?  No one but Native Americans would be here if your proposal prevailed.  You wouldn't be here.

Let's hope Trump challenges the so-called "Europeans" (actually loyal to the caliphate and shariah) who wish to do us harm. In addition, the PC leftist collaborators who have facilitated harm to US citizens should receive their just desserts.

Actually, Abaaoud was a Belgian citizen. He might have traveled to Syria, but since he would have been able to obtain a legal Belgian passport, why would he have had to masquerade as a refugee?

The greatest risk of terrorist attacks in the U.S. is from native-born whites from radical right-wing groups. Why don't we insist that our government protect us from _them_, first?

Trump didn't blow up the GOP, they did that themselves! Trump only moved into the vacuum that was created. Rather like ISIS moving into the vacuum created by Assad.

And, yes, I am suggesting that Trump is as crazy as ISIS!

Rick - thank you for the sensible comment and relevant question.

Refreshing to say the least!
The saying on the tablet the Statue of Liberty should be changed to say "as long as we are not afraid we may accept you but only if you are Christian"

The Refugee Vote is not a failure for Obama.  It is the result of fear-mongering by American legislators after the carnage by Daesh in Paris last Friday.  We don't know if there is a global war against ISIS, it is too early days.  The fearsome publicity and propaganda from ISIS, the New Caliphate,  that they will attack Rome, Washington, New York City, has done the amok PR trick of frightening Americans out of their minds, of attacking their emotions. Hence, today,  the passing of H.R.4038, The American Security Against Foreign Enemies (SAFE) Act of 2015.  Hope is still alive, still the thing with feathers. Evil is afoot among the Muslim zealots as it was afoot 80 years ago when the German/Japanese/Italian Axis rattled its swastikas, rising suns and fasces at the West before WWII, and was mercilessly defeated by the Allies after 6 years of war and millions upon millions dead in Europe. Refugees again rampaging through Europe; among them - undoubtedly - some ISIL evil-doers, too.  Chickens coming home to roost in the present days.

WIlliamson assumes that there was something Obama could have done to keep this law from passing the House.

Republicans have been pushing an anti-immigrant agenda for many years now, but their xenophobia has reached new heights (or lows) in the past couple of months (thanks largely to the Republican presidential candidates, especially Trump and Carson). They would have jumped on the "opportunity" that the Paris attacks presented to advance their anti-immigrant agenda no matter what Obama said or how many refugees he agreed to admit. In fact, the more forcefully Obama stands up for something, the more vigorously the Republicans oppose it.

The only thing Obama could have done to prevent this law would have been implementing this policy himself. THAT would be a failure for Obama, and for the world.

My cat Marcello has done more harm to me than radical jihadists. Let's take a pause and breathe, folks. Who should we REALLY be afraid of ? The bodies piling up here in America seem to be at the hands of angry or disturbed young white men: Oklahoma City, Columbine, Sandy Hook, Aurora Colorado movie theater, etc. Yeah, I know, there's a lot of "catching up to do" with the 9/11 body count, but let's face it - anyone who wants to get in here to do evil will most likely cross the border illegally anyhow - regardless of how high a wall we build or how much money we throw at Homeland Security.
Well written. There are a lot of us (who are white) who stand with the president not because of his color but because he is right.

Portraying the Republicans who oppose anything Obama, as serious statespersons is sad; and perhaps the only thing worse are the courage-less Democrats. This entire “show” is another example of the real failure of principle committed by our nation over so many years; a failure that has inflicted so much pain and suffering on people of color. “Misjudge the mood?” The “mood” is clearly ugly; after all, who are the Republican presidential frontrunners? Has Mr. Obama somehow missed that “mood? The numerous attempts to overturn “Obamacare”; or to restrict the votes of Black Americans, the insults and the marginalization of Latinos; has the POTUS missed all of those ugly congressional signs? He may be the POTUS, but I seriously doubt (after the weekly police killing of a Black unarmed citizen); that like countless other Black Americans, he could possibly misjudge the mood of this nation. His mistake is to continue to believe that Republicans, and many members of his own party really consider him their president. But somehow, I think he is also aware of that sad reality…

@William,
A threat from guns doesn't come from an organization whose specific purpose is to kill you and your family. If you know that some group is planning to murder your loved ones I think you have to take precautions.
I'm not sure this distinction will convince you since the anti-gun agenda is a powerful detractor from many problems. And I am anti-gun myself.

If there was no future, that 5th best selling catsup wouldn't be on the shelves!

A supermarket can simply allocate more shelf space to the top four! But political parties can no longer do this sort of thing.

Thus, chaos.

Well, except that, apparently, the leftist government has tied the hands of the police so that they can't act on suspicions, they have to wait until there is an overt act before they can do anything.  So they had suspicions about 168 households in France being involved in terrorist activity, including in Saint Denis, but had to wait until 129 people were murdered before conducting raids.  I doubt Americans would put up with that logic for very long.
Thank you for stating that we need to stop blaming others! How we take collective action and create solidarity will matter to all generations and citizens.

This opinion article is ridiculous. Yes, what happened in Paris was terrible, but what, exactly, should the government of France have done to prevent this? I am impressed that the police have been able to do as much as they already have, tracking the the lead suspect (only to have that suspect die in a firefight). It is not going to be possible in an open society to guarantee complete security at all times. Let's be realistic. But let us also try to pronounce both short-term and long-term solutions to the problem that we now have, which is ISIS. I don't claim to have such solutions, but I'm not blaming the French government for this.
In a democracy you cannot put all blame on politicians only
And we learned nothing from Neville Chamberlain?

Despite criticism of the author for his concern over islamic radicals in his country, we should remember not to humanize these fundamentalist killers.  They abdicated any humanity years ago and deserve our worst.
Maybe if we stayed out of theirs...
The French have elected several mediocre leaders in succession, and who exactly is to blame for that? Pogo could tell you.
Pubishing this is worthwhile because it shows what French governments and others are up against. The idea that one government can stop this is unrealistic.

Direct democracy: necessary and still risky. Available, however, because of technology and a more educated population.

"The people", if they are to mean anything other than a beer swilling, obese blob of walking flesh, must have the power to overrule the representatives on major, important occasions. We must have the ultimate power in a democracy or otherwise it is a cruel, sad joke wherein lies become myths and myths are celebrated as definitive truth.

Follow me here, please. We began with an almost fearful, truncated democracy whereby only the House of Representatives was to be elected directly. The Senate, originally, by state legislatures. The presidency with the intervening authority of the Electoral College and the actual ability to overrule the voters. Even now, because of the states' winner takes-all-rules, it is possible to be elected president without a majority of the vote (G.W. Bush, 2000).

So, step by careful step, we have moved closer over 240+ yrs. toward an actual democracy, yet a president can still ram or sweet talk us into a war like Iraq that results in thousands of deaths, trillions spent and little but blood and desert sand in thousands of boots as comfort. Never again.

Yes, we are an ignorant, prejudiced mass of humanity but, in the end, we are smarter than those sent to represent us because we vote for ourselves, our families and our nation without the corruption of payments of any sort. Now, we pay the price of bad decisions that others make.
